articleBody.value: At Rochester's Peppermill Restaurant on Wednesday morning, a table of six men, friends and former co-workers, shared coffee, eggs and quiet satisfaction.
Donald Trump had won.
"Put me down as happy," said Gary Doran. "Now if he can just come through with what he promised us."
After a moment's reflection he added, as his friends chortled, "I'm just glad that Hillary didn't win."

In breakfast nooks, office pods, break rooms and study halls — and in diners and coffee shops, those quintessential morning-after gathering spots — the talk Wednesday was all Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump.
Nobody was afraid to express an opinion.
"Everybody here is happy," said Barry Payment, finishing his breakfast in a booth at Olympia Family Restaurant in Gates. "People are tired. I think they want big change."
A friend who shared the booth, Kathy Malowsky, nodded her approval. "I think he's going to change some bad things. I have confidence in him. He's smart."
A few tables over, Nick Nucci said he thought the country had been "going in the wrong direction. Having the same regime in place would have meant the same result," he said.
"I'm confident that this man (Trump) is not a sayer. He's a doer."

Trump, of course, is not just a newcomer to politics but a man who's articulated a variety of political views over the years. To Nucci, though, that's a plus. "He's his own man. I respect the fact that he stood up for what he thought was right."
Others weren't so sanguine about the impending Trump presidency.
"I'm scared. His conciliatory speech last night — it was prepared. It's not his words," said Shannon Traphagen as she stood outside the Long Pond Family Restaurant. "I don't trust him right now."

The fear ran deeper in some circles. For those whose communities have been at odds with the GOP ticket through actions or disparaging words, during the campaign or otherwise, Tuesday’s election brought feelings of shock, pain and frustration. The result introduced an uncertainty about their fellow citizens, but also hardened their determination.

"I  thought that I would never see something like this,” said Julio Vazquez, president of the Rochester Latino Rotary Club and past president and CEO of Ibero-American Action League. "I'm an old man now, in my 70s.
“I don’t want to go anywhere for the next few days. I just don’t want to talk to people. I worry about what I say, or who I say it to.”
'Lesser of two evils'
Traphagen, visiting Greece from her home in Buffalo, was one of many people who observed Wednesday morning that neither candidate had won their heart.
"I was not for Donald Trump. I was not for Hillary Clinton either, but I voted for her," Traphagen said. "I wasn't enthused about either of them."

Her friend, Meghan Wingate, agreed. "I was not really in support of either one of them. I kind of fell on the side of Trump because it was a vote against Hillary," she said. "But I'm very conflicted this morning."
Clinton actually carried Monroe County, winning 54 percent of the vote to Trump's 40 percent.
A few miles down the road, outside a Tim Hortons, Katherine Robinson concurred. "I don't know what's happening in America. It was the lesser of two evils," she said.

“I didn’t realize how much people really hated Hillary. I’m shocked, but I’m not in a panic mode," said Allen Johnson, outside James Brown's Place, the diner on Culver Road. "What I am scared about is international relations. In my opinion he’s real thin-skinned and anything can set him off.”

Johnson was one of only a few voters who alluded Wednesday morning to Trump's more mercurial side. Another was Karen Costello. “I used to joke that we need a little bit of a revolution, but this was not the revolution I had in mind. I’m really concerned that we’ve now created an atmosphere where it’s publicly okay to make hate statements," said Costello, who was also at James Brown's.

But a third person outside the Culver Road eatery said Trump took advantage of people's unhappiness with the economy. “The loss of manufacturing jobs over the last 20 years … I think that really energized a lot of people," said David George.
He added the familiar refrain: "And Hillary was just not that popular.”

She was for Sarah Kingsley, 21, who grew up in a strong Democratic family in Rochester, liked Clinton's policies, and had already purchased her plane ticket to the inauguration. This was the first presidential election in which she could vote.

Kingsley woke at 7:30 a.m. Tuesday, and was at the polls at 8 with her parents. "We all dressed up ... wearing red, white and blue," she said. Afterward, they stood in line at Mt. Hope Cemetery to place their "I Voted Today," stickers on Susan B. Anthony's grave. That night, she watched the returns with her three roommates, having prepared a worksheet of each state's electoral votes, ready to count down to the nation's first woman president. The night ended in anger and frustration.

"Hillary has become a champion for me," said the computer science/studio arts double major at the University of Rochester. "She was this strong woman, who isn't necessarily — she is not a nice lady, she is a very confident woman. I see a lot of myself in Hillary. And to see her reach this momentous position would have been huge for me."
Instead: "It has been like a waking nightmare."
"We all went to bed at 2 a.m., sobbing. It was pretty terrible. I canceled my plane ticket this morning."
From his office at Nazareth College in Pittsford, Muhammad Shafiq, the former Imam of the Islamic Center of Rochester, talked about the difference between politics and reality.

“Human life is human life — very strange,” said Shafiq, who now works as executive director of the Brian and Jean Hickey Center for Interfaith Studies and Dialogue at Nazareth. “You see, sometimes you get shaken up and eventually you rethink yourself, to stand up again and continue to work. And that is what we will do.”

But the election left Shafiq not feeling well. He canceled his morning appointment, saying: “It is very difficult. It is not an easy thing for me, as a person who is very involved in the community, to digest.”
'Scared and hurt'
By contrast, Scott Fearing hurried to the office Wednesday.

“We were getting calls and emails from people who were feeling really scared and hurt,” said the executive director for the Gay Alliance of the Genesee Valley. “This is a really painful thing for many of our members.”

Both Shafiq and Fearing acknowledge the diversity within their communities. Not everyone was for Clinton. Not everyone was against Trump. But the wave of concern and emotion that rose up starting Tuesday night was anything but divided.

While Trump has been “lukewarm” on LGBT issues, Republican vice-presidential nominee and Indiana Gov. Mike Pence has “an incredibly negative record.” Talk Wednesday was about the U.S. Supreme Court, he said. Will marriage equality stand? Will movement on transgender inclusion and protections and efforts within the Veterans Administration to address matters of sexual orientation and gender identity suddenly stop come January? And will the tenor and tone of the campaign foster more bullying, name calling and harassment?
“The message from the Gay Alliance is we will continue to do the work that is necessary,” Fearing said, “(and) we are more likely to get through it if we are doing it together.”

So on the day after the presidential election, the Gay Alliance was reaching out to mental health professionals and organizing a gathering (from 6 to 9 p.m. Wednesday at the LGBT Resource Center, 100 College Ave.) with no agenda other than to offer support. A similar open and “unapologetic” discussion is expected Friday at the regular meeting of the grassroots organization B.L.A.C.K., which stands for Building Leadership and Community Knowledge. The group has been active in the local Black Lives Matter movement.

The outcome, “makes you think of local politics a lot more,” said group member Adrian Elim, and the need to amplify efforts on criminal justice reform and other civil rights issues. But it also is traumatizing, he said, pointing to racial disparities in election returns.
“This is really just the visual representation of everything we have been talking about,” said Elim, “And now there are just more people ... who have no choice but to confront these things.”

“A lot of people in our community are really, really struggling with this,” Vazquez said. “They are very disappointed. They never thought this country would elect someone like him, you know? He said a lot of mean things, and the fact he was elected by so many people — what does it say about how people in this country think, particularly when it comes to immigrants and women, Muslims."

Kingsley spent the day avoiding news reports. She turned off her Facebook and other notifications. Older friends tell her to move past it, "do Hillary proud, and really be stronger together," she said, already talking mid-term elections and 2020. "It is going to be time to get back up and fight soon."

If there was optimism on the part of those concerned about a Trump administration, it was that President Trump will be different from candidate Trump, that checks and balances, and a system of government designed to change slowly will allow for adjustment; that no group will be singled out because, as Shafiq said, “this is not what America is about.”
At the Peppermill, the Rev. Bradley Strange, eating alone at a table by the window, said "this is the first election where I didn't like either candidate."

Strange said he was an "extremely conservative" lifelong Republican, a description he wouldn't apply to Trump. "His win just amazes me. I'm not upset that he won — I'd rather have him than Hillary. I have a real problem with her honesty."
His consolation for supporting Trump, he said, was he also got a chance to support Trump's running mate. "I'm a huge Mike Pence fan," Strange said.
At the back table, the six "older white guys," as one of them laughingly put it, emphatically denied any support or sympathy for Clinton. And none would admit to being surprised that she had lost.
"No. I think the news coverage people were surprised," said Eric Farmborough.
But Connie Sutton, tucking into breakfast at a nearby table for two, said she was indeed surprised at the result, and displeased as well.
Sutton, who works with developmentally disabled people, said she was particularly turned off by Trump's mocking of a disabled reporter during a campaign speech.
"It's sad that so many people think he's okay," she said.
SORR@Gannett.com
Includes reporting by staff writer Gary Craig
From our Facebook page
Edward Garbowski Jr: An amazing run a and an amazing win. Congrats!

Trevor Esch: I was a Bernie Sanders supporter. I sided with Trump on economics and trade. However on social issues I sided with Hillary. Regardless of who won; we lost. I feel bad for Hillary..regardless of what anybody says against her; She did dedicate her WHOLE life to public service.

Richard Kaplun: Come on people, the difference Trump got the people to come out and vote. Hillary never excited her base. The people she needed to come out and vote for her in those battleground states did not come out for her. She only has herself to blame! Now it's time to move on. Remember if Trump does a lousy job, you can vote him out in four years. That is America and a democracy!

Nancy Whelehan Leport: Who are you trying to kid? He ran on division, promised division and he will deliver on that. Hang onto your la-la land view of this country because the country as you know it just died. A friend said "we broke the world last night."
Roger Moynes: America will be great again.
Rochester reacts

articleBody.value: You'll be OK.

Right now, the day after Election Day, it may feel to you like your country's been hijacked and tossed into a handbasket fast-tracked for hell, or at least a White House remodeled to resemble Biff Tannen's Pleasure Paradise.
You'll get over that.
Just like you got over your first break-up. Just like you laughed again after losing a loved one. Just like you found joy after the last time the "wrong" candidate was thrust into the Oval Office.
You'll be all right. Give it a week, maybe two.

That's about how long it takes for that punch-in-the-gut feeling of your candidate losing a presidential election to subside, according to a study published in the Journal of Experimental Political Science.

"Losing (an election) is painful, at least in the short run," the study read. "Losing an election appears to dominate the pain caused by national tragedies, even among those particularly connected to (the tragedies)."

The authors analyzed polls measuring the happiness of people who identified as either Democrats or Republicans before and after the 2012 election. That was back when professional prognosticators still had a grasp on reality.

Nevertheless, they found that Republicans were so bummed when President Obama won that their drop in happiness was greater than that experienced by respondents with children after the Newtown school shooting and by respondents from Boston after the marathon bombings.
But the same study also confirmed the findings of previous happiness polls — people get over their loss.
"Despite the strength of the loss, happiness appears to recover within a week, consistent with research on people's tendency to adapt to bad events more quickly than expected," the study read.
In other words, we tend to overestimate how much pain we'll feel when we experience an outcome we've dreaded.

"One of the things you can't really write in an academic paper but I can say to you is that losing an election, for so many people, is like theater or a movie with a disappointing ending," said co-author Jason Snyder, an assistant professor at the University of Utah.
"But then the story is over and now they go and try to find the next thing," Snyder continued. "That's really what we see and it seems to be very consistent."
Now, the vitriol of the 2016 election was one for the history books. Polls suggested that never were two major party candidates for the presidency more reviled by the electorate.
The dynamics of this election are likely to underlie our politics for the foreseeable future. To that extent, the theory that you'll move on from the pain of your loss in a week may not hold.
But you'll move on. Eventually.
A 2008 poll found that John McCain's supporters anticipated being far unhappier upon his defeat than they turned out to be when he did lose.

Similarly, a poll of voters in the 1994 Texas gubernatorial election between George W. Bush and Ann Richards found most reported being just as happy, or sad, as they had been a month before the election.
Take solace in that. Elections sting their losers far more than they cheer up their winners, but that winning feeling is just as ephemeral as the sting.
By Thanksgiving, everyone you know, regardless of whom they voted for, will have returned to the tedium of their daily lives.
They'll be commuting to work, shuttling kids to after-school events, standing in the supermarket checkout line and griping about the price of gas. Even the TV pundits will have moved on.
These pedestrian concerns have a far greater influence on our mental and physical health than the results of any election.
But if you really want to hold a grudge, you can always get one of those bumper stickers that read, "Don't Blame Me, I Voted for Her."
David Andreatta is a Democrat and Chronicle columnist. He can be reached at dandreatta@gannett.com.

articleBody.value: Voters gave Democrats a foothold in the Republican-controlled halls of Monroe County government on Tuesday, electing Adam Bello to a full term as Monroe County Clerk, while returning U.S. Rep. Louise Slaughter to a Republican-controlled House of Representatives.

Monroe County went for Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in the presidential election. Incumbents ruled the day in local down ballot races. And in the 133rd state Assembly district, upended by the death of incumbent Republican Bill Nojay days before the primary, former GOP state Assemblyman Joe Errigo, the party's chosen replacement, was leading in unofficial vote tallies at press time.
So as a region and a nation awakes from an exhausting and often ugly campaign season bent on change, what do they find?

"The very depressing answer to that is, regardless of the outcome, I think it is going to be status quo," said Kathleen Donovan, assistant professor political science at St. John Fisher College. "All of these problems, this deep divide, is still going to be there. This gridlock is still going to be there.
"All of this is not going away on Nov. 9," she said, "as much as we would like it to."

In other notable races, GOP congressional incumbents Chris Collins, Tom Reed and John Katko had either declared victory or were leading in their respective races. New York state Assemblyman Harry Bronson, D-Rochester, easily won in the 138th District, covering Chili, Henrietta and parts of Rochester. Voters similarly returned Republican Sens. Joseph Robach of Irondequoit and Michael Ranzenhofer of Amherst. All results are unofficial and incomplete.

"I really am deeply humbled and delighted by the results tonight," said Bello, 36, of Irondequoit, who was seeking his first elected term after being appointed to the clerk's post in March by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to fill a vacancy created when Cheryl Dinolfo moved to the county executive’s office. "I am very proud of the campaign we ran ... and didn’t get drawn into the negativity."

Bello won 58 percent of the vote, according to unofficial tallies. Looking ahead, he said he is focused on issues of zombie properties and modernizing the office, including with a new e-file system. Asked about his political aspirations, he said: "I learned a long time ago, do your job and do it great, and the future takes care of itself. I am fully committed to the clerk's office. We have a lot of work to do."
The clerk's office launched both Dinolfo and, before her, Maggie Brooks to the county's top post. Three clerks preceding Brooks left for jobs in state government.

Republican challenger and Greece Town Clerk Cheryl Rozzi, 55, similar expressed pride in her campaign, adding: "Although I am greatly disappointed in the results of this election, I know I will still wake up tomorrow and be the town clerk of the town of Greece, and I will be able to serve the 100,000 people of Greece."

Two years ago, Gates Town Supervisor Assini came within 900 votes of unseating Slaughter — a midterm election in which low voter turnout caused fits for Democratic congressional incumbents nationwide. But election years, with higher turnout, favor Democrats. And Slaughter, D-Fairport, an incumbent who vastly outspent Assini and had a sizable field operation, was not seriously challenged in the 25th District race this time around, taking nearly 56 percent of the vote.
"We talk about progress being on the ballot," said Slaughter, 87, who heads back to Congress for a 16th term. "We're not falling back."
Assini, 57, said he called Slaughter and wished her well.

"Whenever you have a divisive campaign, you need to come together when it is over," he said. "I truly wish her well. In this case, if Congresswoman Slaughter does not do well, it will have an impact on the people and families in our district. I want her to succeed."
Congressional terms are for two years, with a base salary of $174,000.
Despite the seeming incumbent entrenchment, the campaign season showed a region not unlike the rest of the nation.

"We mirrored the national quest (for change) up here in upstate, particularly Western New York," said Timothy Kneeland, chairman of the history and political science department at Nazareth College, noting the popularity of Trump and Bernie Sanders, who narrowly lost Monroe County to Clinton in the presidential primary.

"It's economic expectations. Whoever wins Congress and the White House, they are going to have to see that," Kneeland continued in an interview before election results were known, pointing to predictions of another recessions, worries of job loss or, for millennials, no jobs to come by. "It is anxiety and fear about things that haven’t happened yet. Politics is often about that. You need reassuring."
Where election years typically favor Democrats, the mid-terms tend to favor Republicans. And as elections go, two years is not that far off.
BDSHARP@Gannett.com
Includes reporting by staff writers James Goodman and Meaghan M. McDermott.

articleBody.value: ALBANY - Hillary Clinton won big (in New York). Chuck Schumer won, but lost. And the state Senate will likely stay in GOP hands.
Here's four things you need to know about Election Day in New York:
Clinton wins big in NYC
In a presidential race that often defied conventional wisdom, Hillary Clinton's win in New York was an exception.
The Democratic candidate won big in New York City, fared well in the city's closest suburbs and won upstate's largest population centers en route to picking 59 percent of the statewide vote.
Generally speaking, those are the traditional Democratic strongholds in New York, which has more than twice as many Democrats as Republicans.

Trump, meanwhile, fared well in rural upstate counties, as well as in Suffolk County on Long Island, which he won with about 53 percent of the vote. Statewide, Trump received about 37 percent of the vote.
Clinton's best New York county was the Bronx, where she picked up more than 88 percent of the vote. Trump's was rural Wyoming County, where he received 73 percent of the vote.
MAP: How Trump, Clinton fared in NY state, by county
Schumer in the minority
Sen. Charles Schumer handily won re-election, receiving 70 percent of the vote in his race against Republican Wendy Long.
But his bid to become Senate majority leader fell short.
As the Senate Democrats' leader-in-waiting, Schumer had a shot to become the powerful majority leaders had his party picked up five seats in the Senate.
The effort was unsuccessful. By mid-day Wednesday, Republicans were declared winners in 51 Senate races nationwide, with Democrats picking up 47.
Before the nationwide results were in, Schumer sounded an optimistic tone.
"You know, tonight, there's another thing that could happen: There's a chance I could become majority leader of the U.S. Senate," he said during his victory speech Tuesday night.
In a statement Wednesday, Schumer acknowledged Democrats would be in the minority.
"It is time for the country to come together and heal the bitter wounds from the campaign," he said.
It's good to be an incumbent
The big winners in the tightly contested, expensive race for control of the state Senate: Incumbents.
All but one incumbent state senator who sought re-election either won outright Tuesday or held a lead heading in to absentee ballot counts.

That includes Sens. George Latimer, D-Rye, Westchester County; Terrence Murphy, R-Yorktown, Westchester County; and Sue Serino, R-Hyde Park, Dutchess County, all of whom were targets of the opposing party.
The exception was Long Island Republican Michael Venditto, who trailed Democratic opponent John Brooks by just 33 votes.
Republicans, meanwhile, flipped a seat in the Buffalo area that was previously held by Democratic Sen. Marc Panepinto, who did not seek re-election.

If unofficial results hold on Long Island, Republicans would hold 31 seats. With Brooklyn Sen. Simcha Felder, a Democrat who sits with Republicans, the GOP would have just enough to control the majority in the 63-seat Senate.
GOP holds strong
Republicans, despite the statewide victories of Clinton and Schumer, were able to retain their nine seats in the U.S. House.

In the two open seats currently held by Republicans, they kept both: John Faso won the open seat in the Hudson Valley being vacated by Chris Gibson, and Claudia Tenney won a central New York seat being vacated by Richard Hanna.
Democrats kept their 18 House seats.
"Tonight was a huge win for our New York Republican congressional delegation,” state GOP chairman Ed Cox said in a statement.
“We secured victories in the two hotly contested open seats, a true testament to the quality of our candidates and our nominee at the top of the ticket, Donald Trump.”

articleBody.value: Monroe County voters helped decide four state Senate races on Tuesday, and rubber-stamp two uncontested races.
The position of state senator pays a base salary of $79,500, plus per diems and stipends for committee work. State senators serve two-year terms.
54th District
Canandaigua town supervisor Pamela Helming prevailed in a three-way race for the 54th District among candidates on the Republican, Reform and Democratic party lines.

Helming ran on the Republican line, while Floyd Rayburn, an Ontario County businessman, ran on the Reform line and Kenan Baldridge, the town supervisor of Rose, Wayne County, ran on the Democratic line.
Based on unofficial numbers, Helming took 61 percent of the vote, while Baldridge took about 33 percent, and Rayburn took about 7 percent, according to The Associated Press.
The district includes parts of Monroe, Ontario, Wayne, Tompkins, Seneca and Cayuga counties.
They vied to fill the shoes of longtime Sen. Michael Nozzolio, R-Fayette, Seneca County, who served in the position for over 20 years and did not seek re-election after undergoing open heart surgery.
Helming, 54, won the Republican primary, and also ran on the Conservative and Independence lines on Nov. 8.
Rayburn, 61, of Rushville, who came within roughly 200 votes of besting Helming in the Republican primary, clinched a victory on the Reform line to stay in the general election.
Helming has pledged to support education, cut taxes and push ethics reform in state government.

Rayburn ran on a platform of business regulation reform, such as legislation changes regarding worker’s compensation; ethics reform and job creation. He is the owner of F.G. Rayburn Mason Contractors Inc., a Hopewell masonry firm.

Baldridge, 67, has served several terms as Rose town supervisor since 2012, and has over 20 years of nonprofit and consulting experience. His focus was on ethics reform in Albany, environmental issues such as landfill expansion and infrastructure and supporting education, he said.
56th District
Joseph Robach, a Republican who has represented the 56th district since 2003, bested challenger Democrat Ann C. Lewis Tuesday.
Unofficial results show Robach took about 64 percent of the vote, while Lewis took 36 percent, according to the Monroe County Board of Elections.
The district includes the towns of Brighton, Clarkson, Gates, Greece, Hamlin, Parma, and parts of the city of Rochester.

As chairman of the Senate’s transportation committee, Robach fought for upstate funding parity with the downstate MTA, successfully securing $27.1 billion in state aid to improve and repair roads and bridges.
Robach served in the Assembly from 1991 to 2002 before being elected to the state Senate.

Lewis has been critical of Robach’s work leading the transportation committee, citing news reports that New York has the worst roads and bridges in the country. It’s one of several issues she said she would have addressed. She works as a teacher and has lived in the city’s Corn Hill district for more than 20 years.

Robach, 58, of Greece, said his top priorities are job development for the local workforce, ensuring schools and classrooms have the resources they need for a first-class education and making sure that Rochester and Monroe County residents have a strong and effective voice in Albany.

Lewis, 51, said her top priorities were creating well-paying clean energy jobs, making sure elderly, lower income, disabled and veterans needs are a priority, increasing school budgets, and making college affordable.
59th District
After two re-election campaigns in which he ran unopposed, Republican state Senator Patrick Gallivan appeared to have overcome a Democratic challenger this time around.
Unofficial numbers showed Gallivan taking about 73 percent of the vote, while opponent Thomas Casey took 27 percent, according to The Associated Press.

Casey’s campaign was predicated on his fervent dislike for the system that makes Albany incumbents like Gallivan so hard to beat. “Albany is now owned by the incumbents who put the special interests first, not the people,” he said.
Nearly two-thirds of the voters in the district live in suburban Erie County, where both Republican incumbent Patrick Gallivan and Democratic challenger Tom Casey live.
The district also includes Wyoming County; eight towns in western and northern Livingston County, including Caledonia, Avon, Lima and Geneseo; and the Monroe County towns of Henrietta and Wheatland.
Gallivan ran on the Republican, Conservative, Independence and Reform party lines this fall. Casey ran only on the Democratic line.

Gallivan was first elected to the state Senate in November 2010. He served in the State Police and as Erie County sheriff for eight years. Gallivan chairs the Senate committee on Crime Victims, Crime and Correction.

Gallivan, 55, supported the state cap on local property taxes and voted for state budgets that have held spending growth to just 2 percent annually. He also supported legislation that froze counties’ contributions to Medicaid.
Going forward, Gallivan said he would continue to push for economic development, fiscal responsibility and regulatory reform.

Casey, 68, of East Aurora, has run unsuccessfully for the state Legislature four times previously. He is a retired environmental engineer and designed sewer systems and treatment plants for local governments in the region.
He said his top goal was to end gerrymandered districts and establish term limits.
61st District
Incumbent Republican Michael Ranzenhofer stood up to Democratic Erie County legislator Thomas Loughran's challenge in the 61st District.
With 98 percent of districts reporting unofficial tallies, according to The Associated Press, Ranzerhofer took about 58 percent of the vote, while Loughran took about 40 percent.
Ranzenhofer, 62, of Williamsville, was first elected to state Senate in 2008 and was vying for a fifth term. He is a lawyer by trade, but was an Erie County legislator from 1989 to 2008.
The district includes Chili, Riga, Churchville, parts of Rochester, all of Genesee County and part of Erie County.
After joining the state Senate, Ranzenhofer went on to become the Corporations, Authorities and Commissions Committee chair, and said he built his candidacy off the work he has done as a senator.
He also noted his work to put a 2 percent cap on property tax increases in upstate New York. The cap “has saved homeowners and business billions,” the senator said.
Ranzenhofer said his top goal was formulating economic policy to help create solid jobs. He also said he wanted to work on lowering property taxes and corruption at the state government level.
Both candidates have had long careers in local government, and said they wanted to create legislation that combats corruption in state government.

Loughran, 65, won a spot on the November ballot in part by defeating a fellow Working Families candidate in the September primary. He appeared on the Working Families and Democratic lines on the ballot.

Loughran was a businessman who opened and operated a restaurant in the late 1970s and then sold it after 38 years. He has been an Erie County legislator for 11 years. He also served stints on the Amherst Planning Board and Amherst Town Board.

He said his top goal was to place term limits on leadership positions in the Assembly and Senate, and proposed a six-year term on majority and minority speakers and chairs of committees and subcommittees.
55th District
Perinton Republican Rich Funke, 67, ran unopposed for a second term.

The district comprises the eastern Monroe County towns of Irondequoit, Penfield, Perinton, Pittsford, Mendon and Rush and the western Ontario County towns of Victor, East Bloomfield, West Bloomfield, Richmond, Bristol, South Bristol, Canadice and Naples.
62nd District
Robert Ortt, 37, the former mayor of North Tonawanda ran unopposed on the Republican, Conservative, Independence and Reform party lines.
The district covers all of Niagara and Orleans counties and the towns of Sweden and Ogden in Monroe County.
STADDEO@Gannett.com
Includes reporting by staff writers Sarah Taddeo, Sean Lahman, Steve Orr and Will Cleveland.

articleBody.value: Note: All results are unofficial and incomplete.
Two Democrats handily won races for town supervisor and town council in Irondequoit.
Democratic Supervisor Dave Seeley with roughly 71 percent of the vote turned aside a challenge by Republican Christopher Burns, 16,803 to 6,775, according to the Monroe County Board of Elections.
"Irondequoit's best days are ahead," Seeley said Tuesday night at the Democratic Party's rally.
Seeley has held the job since April, after he was appointed by the Town Board to fill a vacancy created when Adam Bello became county clerk. Burns tried unsuccessfully to be appointed to the post.
A former senior adviser to state Assembly Majority Leader Joseph Morelle, D-Irondequoit, Seeley also ran on the Conservative, Independence and Working Families lines.
The election is to see out the final year of Bello's term as town supervisor. The post pays a salary of $85,000.
Seeley will need to stand again in 2017.
Meanwhile, Democrat Peter Wehner defeated Republican James Shafer for a seat on the Town Board.
Wehner won with roughly 63 percent or about 14,781 votes, according to the Board of Elections. Shafer had 8,410 votes. The Town Board seat pays a salary of $12,340.
Pittsford Town Justice
Robert Shaddock appears to have turned away John Ferlicca in a tight race for Pittsford town justice.
Shaddock won with 7,186 votes versus Ferlicca’s 6,811, according to the Board of Elections. The margin will likely change when absentee ballots are counted in during the upcoming days.

Shaddock, a Republican appearing on the Conservative, Independence and Reform lines, was appointed roughly a year ago to fill the vacancy created after William K. Taylor took a position with the state Supreme Court. The Pittsford post pays $39,820 annually and carries a four-year term.
Ferlicca appeared on the Democratic and Working Families lines.
Gates Town Board
David DiCaro, a director of safety and security at St. John Fisher College, won a seat on the Gates Town Board.
He defeated Silvano Orsi, 7,029 to 4,681, according to the Board of Elections.
DiCaro will finish the remaining year left on Frank Allkofer’s term. Allkofer vacated the post when he was elected to the County Legislature. The salary for the position is $15,439.
Parma referendum
Residents in Parma decided to keep the highway superintendent as an elected position, rather than allow the town board to appoint someone to head up the highway department.
The measure was defeated 4,268 to 2,564, according to the Board of Elections.
Uncontested races
The following candidates — according to the Board of Elections — went unchallenged and won their races:

• John Falk for Brighton Town Justice.
  • Mark DeCory for Chili Town Board.
  • Daniel Barlow for Parma Town Board.
  • Donald Knab Jr., Rush town justice.
TCLAUSEN@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: Republican Joe Errigo will return to the New York State Assembly under unusual circumstances after defeating Democrat Barbara Baer by a healthy margin Tuesday night.
Errigo, who lives in Conesus, Livingston County, won 57 percent of the vote to Baer's 43 percent, according to unofficial results from The Associated Press.

On a night of blockbuster results in races for higher office — of course,  Donald Trump winning the presidency, but also Louise Slaughter fending off a challenge in the House of Representatives and Adam Bello winning the Monroe County Clerk's position for the Democrats — the status quo remained mostly intact in the local state Assembly delegation.

Errigo's victory means Republicans will retain the 133rd District seat after the death of Bill Nojay. Republican Mark Johns and Democrat Harry Bronson both beat off challengers and four other assemblymen ran unopposed.

Errigo, 78, served in the Assembly from 2000 to 2010. He was pulled out of retirement at the last moment after Nojay died by suicide Sept. 9. Nojay won the primary posthumously, and the Republican party chairmen of Livingston, Steuben and Monroe counties tapped Errigo, 78, to fill his spot on the ballot for the 133rd Assembly district.
"It's a win," Errigo said. "It's just hard work, going out and talking to the people."

The district covers overwhelmingly rural and conservative portions of the three counties, and Errigo saw little reason to campaign vigorously. In his only prominent appearance, he claimed on WXXI-AM 1370's Connections that President Barack Obama has encouraged black people to kill white people.
Like Nojay, Errigo favors smaller government, lower taxes and a repeal of gun control legislation.
"They dealt with me years ago — the Farm Bureau, the gun people, not that that's the most important thing," he said. "It was just meeting with the constituents."
Baer, of Pittsford, won Monroe County by about 700 votes, but lost too much ground in Livingston and Steuben counties.

Bronson, representing parts of the city of Rochester and town of Chili in the 138th district, emerged from a tightly contested Democratic primary against former television journalist Rachel Barnhart. In Tuesday's general election, he easily dispatched of Republican challenger Peter Zinck with 64 percent of the vote, according to unofficial results.
It was a battle of restaurateurs — Bronson co-owns the Equal=Grounds coffee shop in the South Wedge, while Zinck co-owns Lovin' Cup in Henrietta.
"This is a wonderful victory," Bronson said. "We put family first."

It will be Bronson's third term in the Legislature. He has made priorities of an increased minimum wage and equality for people in the LGBTQ community. Zinck, on the other hand, disagreed with the state's action to raise the minimum wage for some people.
In the 135th district, covering Penfield, Perinton, Webster and East Rochester, Republican incumbent Mark Johns defeated Democratic challenger Dorothy Styk with 60 percent of the vote.

Styk, a former Monroe County legislator who switched her affiliation from Republican to Democrat, had sought to capitalize on the indictments of  former Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and former Senate Majority Leader Dean Skelos and position herself as representing better ethical judgment.
Johns has long advocated for term limits for legislators. If limits had been in place, he pointed out, neither Silver nor Skelos would have been in office this year.
In contests where incumbents had no challengers:

• Republican Peter Lawrence of Greece will serve another term in the 134th District.
  • Democrat Joe Morelle of Irondequoit will serve another term in the 136th District.
  • Democrat David Gantt of Rochester will serve another term in the 137th District.
  • Republican Stephen Hawley of Batavia will serve another term in the 139th District.
Members of the New York State Assembly earn a $79,500 base salary. The Democrats have a firm grip on the Assembly thanks to overwhelming numbers in New York City.
Includes reporting by staff writers Brian Sharp, Leo Roth, Jeff Spevak, Patti Singer and David Andreatta.

articleBody.value: Republicans appeared to sweep contested judicial races locally, with new judges taking the bench on Family Court, Monroe County Court, and state Supreme Court.
Elected Tuesday to local judgeships were:

• Charles Schiano Jr., a private attorney who has been a Greece town justice since 2002, was elected to state Supreme Court.
  • Sam Valleriani, a legal assistant to a County Court judge, was elected to County Court. He has been a Gates town justice since 2012.
  • Stacey Romeo, a confidential law clerk to state Supreme Court Justice Gail Donofrio, was elected to Family Court.
  • Incumbent City Court JudgeMaija Dixon, a Democrat running unopposed.

The judgeship races were largely under the radar — save some television advertising — but the losses were perhaps especially jarring for Democrats, who have found presidential elections to be years when they can make stronger showings in judicial elections.
State Supreme Court

Schiano was for much of the race the sole candidate seeking the state Supreme Court judgeship for the Seventh Judicial District, which encompasses eight counties. However, about two months before the election, Democrats selected Tonia Ettinger,  a lawyer with the Legal Aid Society of Rochester, to challenge Schiano.
Schiano prevailed with 60 percent of the vote, compared to 37 percent for Ettinger, according to unofficial returns from The Associated Press.

As a justice in one of New York's largest towns, and as a private attorney with significant criminal and civil practice, Schiano will step into the Supreme Court judgeship with ample experience. As a town justice, he adjudicated more than 50,000 cases, from landlord-tenant to disputes to misdemeanor crimes.
During the campaign, he said he had considered a run for state Supreme Court for some time. "It was something I always wanted to do,” he said. “The question was when.”
County Court

Valleriani, who secured five ballot lines in the County Court election, won more than 51 percent of the vote, according to unofficial results. He defeated Melissa Barrett, a court attorney in City Court, who won a Democratic primary.
Valleriani, a former assistant public defender who went into private practice, ran on the Republican, Independent, Conservative, Reform and Working Families party lines.
Valleriani is in his second term as Gates town justice. Before that, he was a teacher in the Rochester City School District, then an assistant public defender and a lawyer in private practice.
Valleriani now works as the court attorney to Monroe County Court Judge John DeMarco, helping with legal research and drafting opinions.
During the campaign, Valleriani highlighted his experience as a town justice.
Family Court

The Family Court race featured two candidates who have unsuccessfully sought office before — Romeo once ran for Irondequoit town justice and her Democratic opponent this year, Maritza Buitrago, last year also lost a race for Family Court.

Romeo, who won 53 percent of the vote, has worked for six years as a legal assistant to Justice Donofrio, who previously was a Family Court judge. That role has allowed her to see the workings of the bench up close, Romeo said during the campaign.
On the bench, she said, she wants "to improve the efficiency of having cases calendared and called on a timely basis."
Romeo also has worked as a referee, a quasi-judicial position that also gave her a taste of a judge's work, she said during the campaign.
Buitrago, the only judicial choice to receive the highest ratings from all of the legal organizations that evaluate candidates, is an assistant public defender with ample experience in Family Court.
City Court
Dixon ran unopposed for City Court this year. She was elected to a second 10-year term.
GCRAIG@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: Republicans held onto the U.S. House in Tuesday's elections, including those in western New York.

Chris Collins declared victory in the 27th District that extends from Buffalo through Rochester's suburbs, while Katko won in western/central New York and Tom Reed defeated Democrat John Plumb in the Southern Tier.

Collins, a 66-year-old outspoken conservative from Clarence, Erie County, was the first congressman to publicly endorse Donald Trump’s presidential campaign back in February. Reed, 44, of Corning, similarly endorsed Trump, while Katko, 54, of Camillus, called for Trump to drop out as recent as last month.
Whether that matters is a question.

"No matter what, the Republicans have already changed what it means to be a Republican," Timothy Kneeland, chairman of the history and political science department at Nazareth College, said in an interview before the election returns. "So Paul Ryan has got to, no matter what, he has got to somehow acknowledge that."

During his four years in office, Collins rose to a seat of prominence within Republican leadership, serving on the House Small Business, Agriculture and Science, Space and Technology committees before being appointed to the influential Energy and Commerce Committee in 2014.

A business owner and former Erie County executive, Collins unseated Democratic Congresswoman Kathy Hochul — now lieutenant governor — back in 2012, and easily won re-election in 2014. Democratic challenger Diana Kastenbaum, 65, is CEO of the tool-and-die operation Pinnacle Manufacturing Company Inc.
The 27th District includes Genesee, Livingston, Orleans and Wyoming counties as well as portions of Erie, Niagara, Ontario and Monroe Counties.

Reed has represented the sprawling 23rd District since 2010. The district covers Chautauqua, Cattaraugus, Allegany, Steuben, Yates, Schuyler, Seneca, Tompkins and Chemung counties and parts of Ontario and Tioga counties. Plumb hails from the Jamestown area.

In the 24th District, Katko beat back a challenge from Democrat Colleen Deacon, former aide at U.S. Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand. The district includes all of Cayuga, Onondaga and Wayne counties and part of Oswego County. It was considered one of just 18 toss-up contests among the 435 House races nationwide, according to the nonpartisan Cook Political Report. Deacon, 39, lives in Syracuse.
BDSHARP@Gannett.com
Includes reporting by staff writers Sarah Taddeo, Meaghan McDermott and the staff of the Elmira Star-Gazette.

articleBody.value: ALBANY -- Sen. Charles Schumer easily won a fourth term Tuesday against underdog candidate Wendy Long.
With the win, the Democratic senator from Brooklyn may end up as one of the most powerful people in Washington.
He is poised to succeed Nevada Sen. Harry Reid as Senate Democratic leader come January.
"Tonight I’m humbled by the trust that my fellow New Yorkers have continued to put in me to do that job — to represent them in the United States Senate," Schumer said at a rally in Manhattan.
"And I promise this: I will work every day to be deserving of your trust."
Long and a pair of third-party candidates were challenging Schumer, who was first elected in 1998.

"I congratulate Wendy Long on a hard-fought race and thank her for stepping forward to run against Washington's special interests and the corrupt political establishment that has left the working men and women of New York behind," said state GOP chairman Ed Cox in a statement.
The race was called by the Associated Press when the polls closed at 9 p.m.
With 71 percent of districts reporting statewide, Schumer was leading 72 percent to 26 percent, according to the Associated Press.
The campaign was never in doubt.
Statewide, incomplete results Tuesday evening showed Schumer was 57 percentage points ahead of Long, 77 percent to 20 percent. Schumer was leading 66.7 percent to 30.9 percent in Monroe County.
Long, a Manhattan attorney, ran for the U.S. Senate before: in 2012 against Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand.
Gillibrand beat Long with 72.2 percent of the statewide vote, besting a modern record Schumer set when he won his second term in 2004.
Schumer, 65, has never lost an election, and he was first elected to the state Assembly in 1974 at age 23. He then was elected to the U.S. House in 1980.
Long and Schumer had one debate on Oct. 30, where he boasted about being a fighter for the middle class.
Long, 56, countered that Schumer was beholden to special interests, such as big banks and drug companies.
“I’m always there for New Yorkers, and if you give me the honor of re-electing me, I’ll work really hard for the middle class and those trying to get there," Schumer said.
Long said it was time for a change.
“Our country is going down,” Long said in an interview with the USA Today Network Albany Bureau last week.

“I’ve enjoyed the benefits of this country, which has been very good to me. I believe in the idea of sacrifice and fighting for what’s right and giving something back to the country that’s given me so much.”
Schumer's campaign cash dwarfed Long's money, and he was able to pump millions of dollars into other races around the country.
He had $17 million in his war chest last month, while Long had just $154,000.
Two third-party candidates were also on the ballot: Green Party's Robin Laverne Wilson and Libertarian Alex Merced.

articleBody.value: ALBANY – Hillary Clinton cruised to a win Tuesday in New York, easily capturing the 29 electoral votes in the heavily Democratic state she calls home.

Clinton, who served eight years as New York’s junior senator, appeared headed to a wide victory over Republican Donald Trump in the Empire State, home to the both major-party presidential candidates for the first time since 1944.
But in a stunning upset, Trump won the presidency over the favored Clinton.

The vote Tuesday was the latest in a series of big victories for the former first lady and secretary of state in New York, where she won Senate elections in 2000 and 2006 before winning the state’s Democratic presidential primary vote in 2008 and earlier this year.
Trump had repeatedly pledged to remain competitive in his home state, which hadn’t backed a Republican candidate for president since Ronald Reagan’s nationwide landslide in 1984.

But the Trump campaign ultimately opted for a more-traditional strategy, focusing the candidate’s time and resources on battleground states like North Carolina and Florida as public-opinion polls showed him trailing heavily in New York.

Speaking at Clinton's campaign party Tuesday night, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said Trump "fanned the flames of negativity and division." He expressed confidence Clinton would win the national race, even as early returns suggested a tight race.
"This is about who we are as a people," Cuomo said. "That is what this election is about."
Like Trump, Clinton spent much of the presidential campaign swing states, hoping to pick up key electoral votes that could help tip the election.
On Election Day, both candidates stayed right at home.
Clinton and Trump spent the day in New York, casting their ballots before heading to midtown Manhattan for separate parties where they awaited the nationwide results.
At her polling place in Chappaqua, Westchester County, Clinton said casting a ballot for herself is a “most humbling feeling.”
“I’ll do the very best I can if I’m fortunate enough to win today,” Clinton said.
It was the first time New York was home to the Democratic and Republican presidential candidates since Franklin D. Roosevelt defeated then-Gov. Thomas Dewey to win a fourth term.
Public-opinion polls and party enrollment data didn’t leave much suspense in the candidates’ home state, which has more than twice as many Democrats as Republicans.
In incomplete results, Clinton was up 63 percent to 32 percent for Trump in New York.

Clinton cast her ballot Tuesday morning. Before that, she was greeted by hundreds of supporters around 3:30 a.m. at the Westchester County Airport, where she arrived after a late-night rally in North Carolina.
Trump voted at a public school in midtown Manhattan, accompanied by his wife, Melania.
In April, Clinton and Trump cruised to wins in New York’s primaries.
Trump won 60 percent of the GOP vote, easily defeating Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Ohio Gov. John Kasich en route to winning 89 of the state’s 95 Republican delegates.
Clinton received 58 percent of the Democratic vote, collecting 139 New York delegates to Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders’ 108.
In mid-April, Trump said he had a “really good chance” to win New York.

“I think I’ll win New York,” Trump said then in an interview with the USA Today Network’s Albany Bureau. “I think I’ll win Michigan. I think we’ll win states that Republicans don’t even go to in the general election.”
JCampbell1@Gannett.com
Jon Campbell is a staff writer for USA TODAY Network's Albany Bureau.

articleBody.value: Huge crowds queued into the night to pay their respects at Susan B. Anthony's headstone in Rochester's historic Mt. Hope Cemetery.

One by one, they stepped forward to place their "I Voted Today" stickers on Anthony's time-worn headstone — partaking of an Election Day tradition that has gained new meaning with the candidacy of Hillary Clinton, the former senator from New York.

"I'm voting for the first woman president. As a woman I can vote because of the sacrifices she made," said Jillian Paris of Brighton, who affixed her sticker to Anthony's marker about 7 a.m., shortly after sunrise. It was her first visit to Anthony's grave, which made the occasion "a little more special."

By early evening, city officials estimated that around 7,000 people had made it to the Anthony family plot since dawn. Many were women and girls. Those standing in line — some waiting for over two hours — were willing to endure the wait for the chance to approach the simple burial site that has become a shrine to women's rights.

"I am shocked at the number of people who are here today. I never expected this," said Janice Schwind of Rochester, after making it through the line. "I thought I could come in, throw my sticker on there and run off to work. I'm an hour late so far.
"It's making me all choked up to see all the people," she said.

The air was crisp and clear, and the Anthony family plot, atop one of Mt. Hope's hills, was framed by stately trees with their autumn foliage brilliant in the sun. Floodlights and torches lit up the grave site as darkness came, and evening rain didn't deter visitors who came to celebrate Anthony's contribution to U.S. voting as we know it.

Nearly everyone who honored Anthony had friends, or strangers, take their pictures in front of the headstone — which was plastered with "I Voted" stickers, with only her name visible. Yellow flowers, a symbol of women's suffrage; American flags and photos were heaped at the grave stone's foot.

Shortly before noon Rochester Mayor Lovely Warren and then U.S. Rep. Louise Slaughter of Fairport visited the grave site, shaking hands, offering encouraging words and posing for photographs with a parade of voters and their children. "I'm glad to be here to see it," said Slaughter, a Democrat whose district includes Mt. Hope. "And the crowd — I don't think I expected anything like this."

Warren, who called the turnout incredible, passed out commemorative "replacement" stickers bearing Anthony's image and the words "I voted today because of women like her." Slaughter was coaxed into reading aloud the beginning of the Declaration of Sentiments and Resolutions from the groundbreaking 1848 women's rights conference in Seneca Falls
The gathering had the festive air. Many people smiled and laughed in delight at the occasion. Others wept.

Johanna Rehbaum had tears in her eyes as she slung her 14-month-old daughter Grace into a carrying pack. "I want her to know that she was part of this," said Rehbaum, who is eight months pregnant. "When Hillary wins," she added with a smile, "I want her to be part of it."
Jodi Atkin of Irondequoit, who visited the grave site early in the morning, said she was overcome when she went to vote.

"I never cried when I filled out my ballot before. But I realized my daughters — and I have three of them — have the right to vote for a woman. It made my cry," said Atkin, who trekked to the grave site with daughter Jessie. Both were clad in white, which many women chose to wear on Tuesday to honor those who, like Anthony, helped secure their right to vote.

"It's crazy because the first time I came to Susan B. Anthony's grave was on a fourth-grade field trip," said Jessie Atkin. Years later, as a graduate student in Washington, D.C., she taught about Anthony in a class on protest writing.
"To come full circle and be able to come back here after having learned about her and taught about her, to be able to participate here, was really cool," added Jessie, who now lives in Rochester.

Anthony, who died in 1906, was a crusader for temperance, abolition of slavery and women's rights. She co-founded the National Woman Suffrage Association in 1869 and made earning women the right to vote her major cause. She was arrested in Rochester in November 1872 and convicted of illegal voting, though she refused to pay the $100 fine.
The 19th Amendment to the Constitution, known as the Anthony Amendment, gave women the right to vote in 1920.

"If it wasn't for her and the people that worked with her, we wouldn't be voting today. It's as simple as that," said Sherry Gilchrist of Penfield moments after she added her sticker to the headstone at midmorning.

Susan B. Anthony's headstone was thick with multiple layers of stickers by the evening. Others had been placed on her sister Mary's grave marker, on commemorative plaques supplied by the city and on a historical marker nearby.

The crowd grew once rush hour passed, and city officials began making room for the queue and doing their best to move people along. Officials offered to take photographs for visitors as they crouched behind Anthony's headstone, and used several electric carts to ferry people from far-off parking areas. A city employee moved through the crowd offering free bottles of water. Children played among the headstones in the rain while waiting their turn.
Outside, traffic was bumper to bumper in both directions of Mt. Hope Avenue, and nearby side streets were filled with parked cars.

Patricia Corcoran, a volunteer from Friends of Mount Hope Cemetery who was at the grave site before dawn to greet people, said the scene was touching and uplifting. She was struck by the fact that so many young people accompanied their parents to the cemetery.
"You can see it was important for people to bring their children," she said.

"I feel so proud to be a woman today. And I'm proud to bring my daughter here," said Aly Lefkowitz, who brought her 20-month-old daughter Claire with her to Mt. Hope. "You come here with such immense gratitude and hope."
Nora Rubel, who is director of the Susan B. Anthony Institute at the nearby University of Rochester, was another of the many parents who wanted to share the experience with their children.

"I have two daughters. We went to the polls together and we wanted to come here together and put our stickers on the grave," Rubel said. "It's a historic time to choose to come. It's an amazing moment."
SORR@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: ALBANY -- Republicans and Democrats were in a pitched and expensive battle for control of the state Senate, and Republicans were winning key races Tuesday night in the Hudson Valley, Long Island and upstate.

Swing races in the Hudson Valley and western New York were breaking for Republicans, who went into Election Day with a one-seat majority only because a Democrat, Simcha Felder of Brooklyn, sits with them.
Early Wednesday, key races on Long Island were also leaning toward Republicans.

Sen. Sue Serino, R-Hyde Park, Dutchess County, declared victory in a rematch against Democrat Terry Gipson, and Sen. Terrence Murphy, R-Yorktown, Westchester County was also winning against Democrat Alison Boak.
"In an election year defined by divisive negativity, local voters stood up for local control of our community and got behind a positive campaign," Serino said in a statement.
Sen. George Latimer, D-Rye, was winning against Republican Julie Killian in a competitive Westchester race.
Sen. George Amedore, R-Rotterdam, Schenectady County, also won a battleground seat that stretches across the Albany area and into Ulster County.
"I remain committed to being a strong voice for upstate New York and fighting to ensure communities throughout the 46th district get their fair share," he said in a statement.
In Buffalo, Republican Chris Jacobs won, picking up a GOP seat that had been held by Democrat Marc Panepinto, who did not seek re-election.
In the Southern Tier, Sen. Thomas O'Mara, R-Big Flats, Chemung County, was leading Democrat challenger Leslie Danks Burke late Tuesday night.
So if Republicans were able to retain all their Long Island seats, they would have gained one seat overall, giving them 32 members and a majority — as well as Felder.
"Tonight we have grown our majority," said Senate GOP spokesman Scott Reif.
Democrats, though, said it was too soon to determine the final Senate makeup, saying several races on Long Island were too close to call.

"With thousands of votes remaining uncounted in multiple State Senate races, we expect more Democratic candidates to win when all New Yorkers’ voices are heard," said Senate Democratic spokesman Mike Murphy.
Millions of dollars were spent by special-interest groups to try to influence the races.
The state's fiscal policies, social issues and immigration positions are at stake depending on who runs the Senate next year.
There's another twist: There's an Independent Democratic Conference that has previously aided Republicans in the majority.
And the conference is growing: It had five members earlier this year, but now it's up to seven members in the 63-seat conference.
On Monday, the IDC added its seventh member, Sen. Jesse Hamilton, a Democrat from Brooklyn.

"Six years ago, our conference grew out of a mission to make positive change in this state, and today its continued growth is a validation of its success," the conference, headed by Sen. Jeff Klein, D-Bronx, who represents parts of lower Westchester County, said in a statement Monday night.

Republicans have held the Senate majority for most of the last half-century, but Democrats went into this year's elections hopeful they could regain a majority they lost in 2010 after two years marred by scandal.
The presidential race was expected to help Democrats because of high turnout and the state's two-to-one Democratic enrollment edge.
Republicans sought to tout their record, which in working with Democratic Gov. Andrew Cuomo and the Democratic-led Assembly included income-tax cuts, a property-tax cap and record aid for schools.

They've also warned a Democratic-controlled Senate would mean both the legislative and executive branches would be controlled by one party, often citing the pending influence of liberal New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio in attack ads.
Cuomo, meanwhile, had gotten more involved in Senate races than he had during his six years in office.

He actively campaigned for Democrats and transferred some campaign cash to key races, saying it was time for the party to control the Senate after touting his working relationship with Republicans since he took office in 2011.
Democrats said they would support additional ethics and campaign-finance reforms, tuition assistance for immigrants in the country illegally and stronger abortion rights.
"That’s my agenda this year," Cuomo said Sunday in Elmsford, Westchester County, "to have a government that people really trust, together with the competence that we’ve already established.
"So, a Democratic House, a Democratic Senate, new Democrats in the New York State Senate and you’re going to see an entirely different New York and an entirely different America."

articleBody.value: Two years ago, Gates Town Supervisor Mark Assini came within 900 votes of unseating Congresswoman Louise Slaughter — a midterm election in which low voter turnout caused fits for Democratic congressional incumbents nationwide.

Slaughter, D-Fairport, spent $675,000 on that campaign and survived, winning a 15th term. This year? The 87-year-old has a larger field operation, and had spent $1.3 million through Oct. 19, the latest financial disclosure reports, filed this week, show.
"A lot of phone calls are being made," Slaughter said, describing a "heavy project to get out the vote."

Assini, 57, is running a similar shoe-leather campaign as he did before, spending just less than $200,000, walking some 400 miles (he has an app on his smartphone to keep track) and knocking on more than 11,000 doors and promising to term limit himself, if elected, to no more than four terms, or eight years.
Each term is two years, with a base salary of $174,000. The 25th Congressional District covers most of Monroe County.
►Watch: 3 questions for congressional candidates
►Slaughter, Assini show clear differences in debate​
►Debate follow-up Assini's photonics comment
►Assini addresses anti-gay comments made in blog

This time around, the issues are similar: Jobs and health care, spending and politics. And Assini's message is largely unchanged, saying that it is time for a change. In a recent debate, he suggested Slaughter had lost track of her district; that "when you are in Washington too long there become these partisan divides, and they get greater and greater."

Slaughter calls this "probably the most important election," speaking about the White House and balance of power, the potential impact with U.S. Supreme Court appointments, and the country's direction on any number of domestic and international issues. On the spending side, this election still pales in comparison to her 2012 campaign against Republican Maggie Brooks, in which Slaughter spent $2.47 million.

She is critical of Congress: "I know Washington isn't working, and we can't get bills to the floor from my side of the House." But she also disagrees with the characterization of the problem as strictly partisan divide, explaining: "I don't see it as a Republican and Democrat problem. I see it as a Republican problem that they have with the Tea Party." The latter, she said, "does not believe in federal government ... (and) they are piece by bit starving it to death."
► ELECTION 2016 NEWS AND PREVIEWS: Local races | National races

In that recent debate, the only one of the campaign, she repeatedly sought to tie Assini to the GOP's presidential candidate, Donald Trump. Assini is backing Trump. He stays clear of character issues — "I will not defend him," he said — instead basing his support solely on Trump's stances on the economy, trade and the Constitution.

Two years ago, Assini was talking about corporate tax reform, fixing but not repealing the Affordable Care Act, redirecting federal funding of high-speed rail to area roads and bridges, and eliminating poverty through education. His positions remain firm, with an expanded conversation mirroring presidential debates about trade, jobs and border security.

The Affordable Care Act "needs some help," Slaughter agrees, while also defending it for those it has served well. To start, she said, "I want to see a single payer" system. That has been true from the start. Assini is not specific, saying he wants to convene experts as all the proposed fixes he has seen are incomplete.

He wants to tighten border security, but said he does not believe in a religious test for immigrants. Slaughter has supported a slowdown in Syrian refugees coming to the United States, but Assini points to the arrest rate of illegal immigrants locally saying "We have to shut our borders down."
► Electoral Collage: Tips for Election Day

Immigration, Slaughter said, "needs a good overhaul." The last Senate bill was "pretty good," but the House didn't take it up. Pressed for specifics, she said, "I'm not going to say off the top of my head that I would do this, or I would do that."

On trade, Slaughter said she was putting in a bill to give oversight authority of trade bills to the Department of Labor, to ensure rules and trade balances are met. Assini, like Trump, points to China, and alleges theft of intellectual property, manipulation of currency, loss of manufacturing and other jobs all are hurting the U.S. economy.

"The more we outsource, the more wages we suppress," he said, echoing Trump in adding "put America first, and you'll see manufacturing jobs coming back. We can't keep going down this road. The U.S. won't survive as a service economy."

He has challenged Slaughter on photonics, both questioning the job promises and whether she can take credit for securing Rochester's place as a manufacturing hub. Slaughter has pushed back hard, with the support of the Rochester Regional Photonics Cluster among others.
One thing both can agree on: "We have an awful lot ahead of us," Slaughter said. Voters will decide who should represent them on Nov. 8.
BDSHARP@Gannett.com
Coming up

On the Opinion page at DemocratandChronicle.com and on Sunday's Speaking Out page in print editions, Mark Assini and Louise Slaughter answer questions and explain their positions on a variety of issues.
Louise Slaughter
Age: 87.
Resides: Fairport
Party lines: Democratic, Working Families and Women's Equality.
Current job: Member of Congress in her 15th term.
Top goal(s): Jobs, economy and wages.
Mark Assini
Age: 57.
Resides: Gates
Party lines: Republican, Conservative, Independence and Reform.
Current job: Gates town supervisor.
Top goal(s): Jobs, economy and wages.

content.shortHeadline: Slaughter, Assini face off again
content.about: Two years ago, Gates Town Supervisor Mark Assini came within 900 votes of unseating Congresswoman Louise Slaughter — a midterm election in which low voter turnout caused fits for Democratic congressional incumbents nationwide.Slaughter, D-Fairport, spent $675,000 on that campaign and survived, winning a 15th term. This year? The 87-year-old has a larger field operation, and had spent $1.3 million through Oct. 19, the latest financial disclosure reports, filed this week, show."A lot of phone calls are being made," Slaughter said, describing a "heavy project to get out the vote."Assini, 57, is running a similar shoe-leather campaign as he did before, spending just less than $200,000, walking some 400 miles (he has an app on his smartphone to keep track) and knocking on more than 11,000 doors and promising to term limit himself, if elected, to no more than four terms, or eight years.

articleBody.value: ALBANY - Charles Schumer, New York’s longtime senior senator, could become one of the most powerful people in Washington should a handful of Senate races bounce the Democrats’ way Tuesday.
First, though, he has to win re-election.

Schumer is facing a challenge from Republican Wendy Long and a pair of third-party candidates — his last remaining roadblocks to becoming Senate Democratic leader, a post he’s set to assume following Harry Reid’s retirement early next year.

The Brooklyn Democrat isn’t leaving anything to chance: He has tapped into his formidable campaign account to blanket New York’s airwaves with advertisements highlighting everything from his lengthy New York record to his support for keeping the Buffalo Bills from leaving to his preference for flip phones.

Long, a Manhattan lawyer, has countered with a largely grassroots campaign, tapping small-dollar donors to fund a comparatively shoestring budget while acting as her own scheduler. She has often driven herself to events across the state as she seeks to block Schumer from winning a fourth six-year term.
► ELECTION 2016 NEWS AND PREVIEWS: Local races | National races

Her challenge is daunting: Schumer has never lost an election dating back to his time in the state Assembly beginning in 1974, and public-opinion polls have consistently shown he remains popular with New York voters.

“It appears that it’s going to be an issue of by how much rather than an issue of who will win,” Siena pollster Steve Greenberg said of the Schumer-Long race. “Chuck Schumer is in a very safe position as he coasts to a re-election for his fourth term.”

A Siena College poll last month showed Schumer with a 66 percent to 27 percent lead over Long among likely voters, which would be one of the largest margins of victory in a statewide election in modern New York history.
Since 2001, Schumer has been viewed favorably by no fewer than 54 percent of New York voters, according to Siena.
He was first elected to the Senate in 1998 after serving in the House of Representatives since 1980.

Schumer and Long faced off Sunday in their lone debate, in which Schumer promoted himself as a champion for the middle class while Long repeatedly criticized contributions to his campaign from Wall Street and pharmaceutical companies.

“I’m also always there when there’s a crisis, whether it’s 9/11 or Sandy downstate, the horrible snowstorm upstate or the floods in Binghamton,” Schumer said. “I’m always there for New Yorkers, and if you give me the honor of re-electing me, I’ll work really hard for the middle class and those trying to get there.”
A Dartmouth grad, Long was a clerk to Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas before serving as an attorney with Kirkland & Ellis LLP, a major international law firm.

In 2009, Long took an active role in opposing President Barack Obama’s nomination of Justice Sonia Sotomayor to the Supreme Court. At the time, Long was chief counsel for the right-leaning Judicial Confirmation Network.
It’s her second run for office. In 2012, Long was defeated by Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, who racked up 72.2 percent of the statewide vote — a state record previously held by Schumer.

“Our country is going down,” Long said in an interview this week. “I’ve enjoyed the benefits of this country, which has been very good to me. I believe in the idea of sacrifice and fighting for what’s right and giving something back to the country that’s given me so much.”
Long, 56, has struggled to gain name recognition in New York, hamstrung in part by a tight budget that hurt her ability to air television advertisements.
Federal Elections Commission filings show Long’s campaign has about $153,856 on hand after raising $601,270 since the start of 2015.
Schumer’s campaign, meanwhile, has more than $17 million on hand, even after transferring millions of dollars to fellow Democrats in other states.
Should Schumer, 65, win, he could rise to the powerful position of Senate majority leader, though it will depend on races in other states.
Republicans currently control 54 seats in the 100-seat U.S. Senate, meaning Democrats would have to pick up a handful of seats in order to flip control of the chamber.
Greenberg, the Siena pollster, said Schumer’s prominent national role isn’t what fuels his solid poll numbers in New York.

“For the majority of New Yorkers, I don’t believe Senator Schumer’s potential to be the minority leader or majority leader plays into how they feel about him as much as what they already know about him,” Greenberg said.
A pair of third-party candidates are also seeking to unseat Schumer.
Robin Laverne Wilson, a Brooklyn-based graduate student and activist known by the nickname “Dragonfly,” is the Green Party candidate.

Wilson is running on a platform promoting renewable energy and a shift away from fossil fuels, as well as an end to “mass surveillance and incarceration,” according to her website. She also supports both medical and recreational marijuana.
The Libertarian Party candidate is Alex Merced, a New York City-based activist and social media consultant who has been active in his party.
He backs a Libertarian platform of getting government out of education and housing lending, as well as abolishing the U.S. Department of Education.
JCAMPBELL1@gannett.com
Jon Campbell is a staff writer with USA TODAY Network’s Albany Bureau.
Meet the candidates
Charles Schumer
Party: Democrat
Residence: Brooklyn
Seeking his fourth term as U.S. senator. Previously served in House of Representatives from 1981 through 1998 and state Assembly from 1975 through 1980.
Wendy Long
Party: Republican
Residence: Manhattan

An attorney making her second run for a U.S. Senate seat in New York. Previously worked for Kirkland & Ellis LLP, a major international law firm. Helped found the Judicial Confirmation Network. Clerked for U.S. Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas.
Robin Laverne Wilson
Party: Green
Residence: Brooklyn

A graduate student and activist who goes by the moniker “Dragonfly.” Daughter of an Army veteran, Wilson graduated from Rutgers University and is seeking a master’s degree in applied theater from the CUNY School of Professional Studies.
Alex Merced
Party: Libertarian
Residence: New York City

A social media and marketing consultant who is active in the Libertarian Party. Ran for New York City public advocate on the Libertarian line in 2013. Moved to New York upon graduation from Bowling Green State University.

articleBody.value: Former senatorial aide Colleen Deacon will challenge Republican incumbent John Katko for the 24th New York Congressional District, which includes Wayne County.

Three Democrats vied to oppose freshman Congressman Katko in September’s primary, and Deacon won out over Syracuse University professor Eric Kingson of Manlius and lawyer Steve Williams of Baldwinsville, with around 48 percent of the vote. She is endorsed by Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, her former boss, along with Sen. Charles Schumer and Syracuse Mayor Stephanie Miner.
Congressional representatives run for two-year terms with a base salary of $174,000. Katko defeated Democratic Rep. Dan Maffei for the seat in 2014.

The seat has flipped back and forth numerous times in the last decade, as the 24th District is rated one of the most competitive in the nation. The district includes all of Cayuga, Onondaga and Wayne counties and part of Oswego County.
► ELECTION 2016 NEWS AND PREVIEWS: Local races | National races

According to the nonpartisan Cook Political Report, the 24th District race is one of only 18 tossup contests among a total of 435 House races around the country. A Democrat won the seat in each of the last two presidential election cycles, while a Republican took it back in mid-term elections.

Katko spent about 20 years as a federal prosecutor before running for Congress. His work as a congressman includes preserving the agricultural visa program to ensure area farmers have an ample workforce; introducing legislation on national security and fighting to end the common core mandate.
STADDEO@Gannett.com
Here's what you need to know about the two candidates.
John Katko
Age: 53
Residence: Camillus, Onondaga County
Occupation: Federal prosecutor turned congressman
Party lines: Republican, Conservative, Independence, Reform
Top goals if elected: Ensure national security, create jobs, reform the VA and open up opportunities for veterans and improve healthcare.
Colleen Deacon
Age: 39
Residence: Syracuse, Onondaga County
Occupation: Senatorial aide at Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand’s office, with previous experience in former Syracuse Mayor Matt Driscoll’s office.
Party lines: Democratic, Working Families
Top goals if elected: Support families and address the wage gap, rebuild infrastructure, combat climate change by investing in clean energy and create jobs in the region.
MAP: 24TH CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT
