articleBody.value: The race for the 27th Congressional District pits a two-term Republican incumbent against a Batavia businesswoman making her second bid for public office.
U.S. Rep. Christopher Collins, R-Clarence, Erie County, is an outspoken conservative and was the first congressman to publicly endorse Donald Trump's campaign for the presidency back in February.

Challenger Diana Kastenbaum is CEO of the tool-and-die operation Pinnacle Manufacturing Company Inc. Her most significant prior political experience was as a volunteer for Hillary Clinton's 2008 bid for the Democratic presidential nomination and her time spent volunteering with the Ralph Nader-founded nonprofit consumer advocacy group Public Citizen. She unsuccessfully ran for Batavia City Council in 2013.

Collins, who also owns a number of businesses, is a former Erie County executive who unseated Democratic Congresswoman Kathy Hochul — now lieutenant governor — back in 2012. He was easily reelected in 2014.

During his four years in office, Collins has risen to a seat of prominence within Republican leadership in the House of Representatives, where he previously served on the House Small Business, Agriculture and Science, Space and Technology committees before being appointed to the influential Energy and Commerce Committee in 2014.
► ELECTION 2016 NEWS AND PREVIEWS:Local races | National races

There, Collins said, he's been able to be a strong voice articulating the issues that matter most to western New York, including boosting manufacturing and other businesses via expansion of rural broadband and opposition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal. Recently, he's been involved in passage of the 21st Century Cares Act, which increases funding for the National Institutes of Health and Food and Drug Administration; it is designed to bring more medical treatments and cures to the market faster. He said that bill is expected to pass the Senate during the upcoming lame-duck session and that President Barack Obama has indicated he would sign it.

"That helps fund research for all manners of disease where research and money isn't likely to come from the private sector, and that is a proper and necessary function of the federal government," said Collins, adding that all funding was found by locating offsets elsewhere in the federal budget. "And, we went to the FDA and asked what can Congress do to help you get these important drugs to market faster?"

Upcoming, Collins said he plans to continue his opposition to the controversial Plan 2014, a proposal by the International Joint Commission, the U.S./Canada organization that oversees Lake Ontario, to change its current practices related to governing water levels in the waterway. The plan has support among business owners, environmentalists and many property owners for its benefits to shipping, hydropower and lake ecology, but there's a strong local contingent of opposition, particularly along the lake's southern shoreline from Niagara to Wayne counties. Property owners are concerned about the possibility of increased erosion and higher costs for maintaining their revetments.
Collins said he's looking forward to working with a President Trump and working to repeal Obamacare and rewrite Medicaid to make it more targeted and cost-effective.

Kastenbaum, who also owed a software development and training company in Los Angeles before moving back to her Genesee County hometown in 2013, said she will focus on job creation, protecting Social Security and Medicare, addressing climate change and alternative energy and expanding access to quality education.
She said she's been alarmed by trade deals that don't benefit American workers and sees a need to focus on creating more business and worker-friendly regulation.

"We need to make some changes so things aren't so onerous to American workers and American manufacturers," she said. At the same time, she said, her experience with Pinnacle has shown her "we need to pay our people a livable wage. As a small-business owner, I live in the same community as my employees, they're my workers, my family and my friends and I want to see them do well."
Another top issue for Kastenbaum would be ensuring that veterans are given their due.

"My dad is a 91-year old World War II vet and he comes into the shop every day," she said. "So I know our vets haven't been getting a fair shake and there are things I want to do for vets to make sure red tape is cut and that they have the funding they need for proper health care."

As a political guidepost, Kastenbaum cites former U.S. Rep. Barber Conable, a Genesee County Republican who served in Congress from 1965 to 1985 and was appointed president of the World Bank by President Ronald Reagan in 1986. She said she admires his ability to work across the political aisle.

"He was able to sit down with Democrats and do great things in the Ways and Means Committee, and I very much want to be that type of congressperson," she said. "I want to be able to sit down, look at the hard issues and find ways to pass good, solid legislation. Hopefully, there would be enough people in Congress who feel this way that we would be able to move past the current obstructionism."

The 27th District includes Genesee, Livingston, Orleans and Wyoming counties as well as portions of Erie, Niagara, Ontario and Monroe Counties. According to the state Board of Elections, Republicans in the district have an enrollment edge of 38,056 over Democrats, with a total voter enrollment of 494,868.
According to financial disclosures, Collins' campaign had $1.2 million cash on hand and $500,000 in debt as of Oct. 19, while Kastenbaum had $2,073 on hand and $43,000 in debt.
The election is for a two-year term, with the position paying $174,000 a year.
MCDERMOT@Gannett.com
27th Congressional District Candidates
Christopher Collins
Age: 66
Party Lines: Republican, Conservative, Independence, Reform
Residence: Clarence, Erie County

Job experience: two-term incumbent, small business owner with numerous enterprises, including Innate Immunotheraputics, Mead Suppply, Oxygen Generating Systems International, Schlyer Machine, Volland Electric and ZeptoMetrix Corp.

Top goal: "To remain on my subcommittees, and continue to push for broadband, which will mean things like telemedicine in rural areas, and especially if Donald Trump is elected, working to repeal Obamacare and replacing it and I'm also one of eight members looking to rewrite all of the Medicare laws and come up with an entirely new plan."
Information:  collinsforcongress.com/
Diana Kastenbaum
Age: 65
Party Lines: Democratic
Residence: Batavia, Genesee County
Job experience: CEO, Pinnacle Manufacturing Company

Top goal: "Chances are after the election, we will not have a Democratic Congress, but once there, one of my goals would be to really stop this Congress from being so obstructionist. I'd really extend my hand and reach across the aisle and work with the Republicans to compromise."

articleBody.value: Tom Reed didn't start out with designs on Washington, D.C., even though his college degree is in political science.

Reed's career path took him into the law, but as he started representing more and more local municipalities as part of his legal practice, the Corning native also took more of an interest in public service.
That eventually led to Reed's election as mayor of Corning. But it was a brief stint, as Reed declined to run for a second term, instead setting his political sights much higher.
Reed, a Republican, was already thinking about running for the House of Representatives seat occupied by Democrat and fellow Corning native Eric Massa.
When Massa resigned from what was then the 29th Congressional District seat amid scandal allegations and health concerns, that cemented Reed's resolve.

"It wasn't by design. It was just a continuation of my commitment to serve the public," said Reed, 44. "We saw where the country was going. I thought Obama's policies for America were harmful. We gave people a choice. Also, this is our home. We chose to raise our kids here. I care so deeply about this area. We want to make sure we do everything possible to make sure people can call this home for generations to come."
► ELECTION 2016 NEWS AND PREVIEWS: Local races | National races

Reed defeated Democrat Matt Zeller in a special election in 2010 to represent the sprawling district — which covers much of the Southern Tier and includes Chautauqua, Cattaraugus, Allegany, Steuben, Yates, Schuyler, Seneca, Tompkins and Chemung counties and parts of Ontario and Tioga counties. The last four congressional representatives, going back 30 years, are from Steuben County, with three from Corning.
Reed won re-election in 2012, turning back a stiff challenge from Ithaca-area Democrat Nate Shinagawa. He had an easier time defeating another Tompkins County Democrat, Martha Robertson, in 2014.
This year, Reed's competition comes from the other end of the 23rd Congressional District. Democrat John Plumb of the Jamestown area hopes to unseat the six-year incumbent.
Reed has built much of his campaign message on his commitment to the Southern Tier and efforts to be accessible to constituents across the district.
That's no small task considering the 23rd Congressional District stretches across 11 counties.

"My office has handled over 10,000 constituent cases. We have a private sector mentality. Constituent service is our top priority," Reed said. "There's also the 200-plus town hall meetings we have done. I'm committed to being accessible to the folks we represent. We have 11 counties — the size of New Jersey. I spend a lot of time in the car. Sure it's a challenge but it's a challenge I enjoy. I get a sense of what we should be focusing on in Washington."

Top among the issues to focus on are jobs and the economy, Reed said. He has some direct influence over legislation that affects those concerns as a member of the House Ways and Means Committee and co-chair of the Manufacturing Caucus.
The second top priority is national security and the fight against terrorism — areas where Reed believes the Obama administration has failed.
Reed said he supports Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's positions on immigration reform and concerns over the influx of refugees from Syria and elsewhere.
And while Reed has taken a lot of heat for his endorsement of Trump, he said he's also seen a lot of support for him in the district.

"They see Hillary (Clinton) as part of the system. Hillary is not going to change Washington, D.C.," Reed said. "Our country is very polarized. Obama came into office as a unifier, but that hasn't been the result."
JMurray@Gannett.com
Jeff Murray is a staff writer for the Elmira Star-Gazette.
​Tom Reed
Age: 44.
Political lines: Republican, Conservative and Independence parties.
Resides: Corning.
Job experience: Lawyer in Rochester 1996-99; attorney in Corning 1999 to 2010; mayor of Corning 2008-09; member of the House since 2010.
Information: Go to tomreedforcongress.com.

assets.title: Tom Reed, John Plumb
assets.cutline: Republican Rep. Tom Reed and Democrat John Plumb are the 2016 candidates running in New York's 23rd Congressional District.
assets.caption: Republican Rep. Tom Reed and Democrat John Plumb are the 2016 candidates running in New York's 23rd Congressional District.

articleBody.value: Native New Yorker John Plumb credits his upbringing in the Southern Tier and his service as a U.S. Navy officer for 22 years with shaping his political philosophy.

So what brings Plumb to vie to represent New York's 23rd Congressional District, currently represented by influential incumbent Tom Reed? He feels his home district has been left behind by Washington far too long.

“I feel like I have the ability to make a difference in this part of the country, right here,” Plumb said. “…I’ve seen a good member of Congress knows how to get results and that results are the thing that matter, and I’ve seen bad members of Congress are interested in the charade — where they pretend like they’re doing things — but all they’re doing is what they’re told.”

Plumb was born and raised in Randolph, about 15 miles east of Jamestown, the western reaches of a far-flung district. He has racked up some serious mileage introducing himself to constituents of the more than 7,000-square-mile expanse of New York’s 23rd Congressional District, which for six years has been represented by former Corning mayor Reed, a Republican.
New York's 23rd Congressional District includes Chautauqua, Cattaraugus, Allegany, Steuben, Yates, Schuyler, Seneca, Tompkins and Chemung counties and parts of Ontario and Tioga counties.
► ELECTION 2016 NEWS AND PREVIEWS: Local races | National races

Plumb’s political philosophy was influenced in part by his role as an aide to Colorado U.S. Sen. Ken Salazar, who went on to serve as Secretary of the Interior during President Barack Obama’s first term in office and is currently working with the Hillary Clinton campaign as head of her transition team.

A 1988 graduate of Randolph High School, Plumb graduated from the University of Notre Dame in 1992 on a Naval ROTC scholarship. Exiting school during a residual “draw down” year from Reagan-era cuts to the defense budget, he pursued a master’s degree in physics from the University of Colorado, the only university of its caliber that could offer him a physics degree within his 18-month leave of absence.

When he returned to the Navy as an officer, Plumb lived in six places in five years, sometimes not even bothering to unpack. For a while, his home was the U.S.S. San Juan out of Groton, Connecticut,  a nuclear submarine, where Plumb said his leadership skills flourished and his interest in engineering and specifically, energy policy, were cultivated.
“It’s unbelievably difficult to be on a submarine, but it’s also rewarding,” Plumb said. “You get to develop your leadership skills in a way few things offer.”
But Cattaraugus County, where he was born and raised, has always been home. His first political ad of the season, “Generations,” played specifically to the sentiment of legacy in his area.
In both his platform and in his advertising, Plumb describes his plans to create programs to retain workers in the Southern Tier.

But the main objective of his candidacy is to usurp politicians like his opponent, Reed, he said. In back and forth press releases, both have called each other out as D.C. insiders. One notable Reed email even outlined Plumb as a carpetbagger for leaving the nation’s capital and returning to the district.
Plumb is quick to disagree with that assessment.
“This has always been home for me, this is my home now,” Plumb said. “The concern I have for this district is it continues to get left behind by Washington, and I’m fed up with how Congress is.”

The disadvantages are the fundraising dollars, a category Reed vastly outguns Plumb in, and recognition. In the last election, Reed defeated Martha Robertson, a Democrat labeled by Reed as an "Ithaca liberal," with nearly 63 percent of the vote.
John Plumb
Age: 45
Party line: Democratic Party.
Resides: Randolph, Cattaraugus  County.

Job experience: Commander and captain, Navy Reserve. Commander, U.S. Navy, 1994-2000. Congressional Science and Technology Fellow through the American Association for the Advancement of Science, U.S. Sen. Ken Salazar, 2004-2005. Military Legislative Adviser to United States Secretary of the Interior Salazar, 2005-2009.
Information: Go to www.johnplumbforcongress.com.

articleBody.value: Typically, the race for Monroe County clerk is a bit of a sleeper, generating little by way of controversy and little by way of overarching public interest.
But this year's race seems to be an outlier.
Indeed, Democrat Adam Bello and Republican Cheryl Rozzi are vying for the office this year in what is one of the the most hotly contested local races this season.

In some ways, the race could be viewed as a proxy for larger Monroe County politics: Bello is an up-and-coming Democratic Party star under the tutelage of state Assembly Majority Leader Joseph Morelle, while Rozzi is the pick of Monroe County Republican Committee Chairman and Greece Town Supervisor Bill Reilich, and has been his appointed town clerk since 2014.
► Rozzi, Bello dispute Social Security numbers breach

It's a battle for control of an office that has served as a major launching pad for county politics: County Executive Cheryl Dinolfo served as county clerk for more than 11 years, and her predecessor Maggie Brooks spent six years in the job before her election as county executive in 2003. And three clerks preceding Brooks went on to other jobs in state government.
So far, the Monroe County Republican Committee has spent more than $60,000 on TV ads backing Rozzi, while Bello has spent $40,000 on TV ads and $21,000 on polling.

Bello, 36, of Irondequoit, is seeking his first elected term to the office after being appointed to the seat in March by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to fill a vacancy created when Dinolfo moved to the executive's office. Bello is a former aide to Morelle who served as executive director of the Monroe County Democratic Party from 2007 to 2011 and was chief district attorney administrator from 2012 to 2013. He was elected Irondequoit town supervisor in 2013.

Bello was sworn in as clerk amid controversy spurred by a poorly aimed political attack launched by Reilich, who had sought to raise questions about Bello’s stewardship of Irondequoit, but instead dragged Dinolfo and the entire County of Monroe Industrial Development Agency into an imbroglio with a local small-business owner. Ultimately, four out of seven COMIDA board members resigned. And Dinolfo was forced to issue a public apology.
►Dinolfo apologizes for I-Square mess

Rozzi, 55, was announced by the county GOP as its candidate in May, putting an end to speculation that the Republicans had been courting higher-profile County Legislature President Anthony Daniele for the bid.

Prior to taking the job in Greece, Rozzi served 11 years as deputy clerk and clerk of the Monroe County Legislature, with her total time working for Monroe County approaching three decades. She and her husband, Rick Rozzi, also owned Atlas Fitness in Spencerport from 1995 to 2004. Under their stewardship, that company expanded from a 5,000-square-foot gym with about 250 members to a more than 10,000-square-foot gym with more than 1,800 members.

"I'm not a career politician, I'm a career clerk," said Rozzi, who pledges to serve all four years of her term if elected, and to not seek higher office. "I'm about providing top-notch customer service and if you know me from Greece, you know I'm out at the counter assisting residents and that is where I am most comfortable: putting people first, not party."
► ELECTION 2016 NEWS AND PREVIEWS: Local races | National races
Among her accomplishments, Rozzi said, has been cultivating a reputation as a hard-working professional who does not let politics intrude on the work at hand.
"When I was installed as clerk of the Legislature, I am very proud to say, it was a unanimous vote and I was supported by both Republicans and Democrats," she said.
Among her initiatives in Greece: reconfiguring employee work stations so the service counter is always manned and instituting an online appointment system for people seeking marriage licenses.
"It's all about the people, that is the people's office and politics shouldn't play a role," she said.

Although Bello has only been in office a few months, he has unearthed serious examples of his predecessor's apparent mismanagement: he discovered 20,000 New York state SAFE Act opt-out forms that had never been processed under the Dinolfo administration. The forms were supposed to have been sent on to a judge for approval, and then back to the clerk so the office could note which permit holders had been granted privacy, shielding their names and address from public disclosure. Instead, three years' worth of forms been stuffed into seven drawers of a filing cabinet in Room 101H of the clerk’s office. Bello said the forms will be fully processed by the end of the year.
►Andreatta: Dinolfo shelved gun opt-out forms

And last month, he revealed an investigation that found the Clerk’s Office had been waiving a variety of fees for certain persons and businesses dating as far back as 2008, to the tune of more than $35,000. Most troubling was an apparent practice of waiving a $15 passport processing fee that the federal government says the office was legally required to collect. The U.S. State Department is investigating.
►UPDATE: U.S.: County passport fee waivers illegal

As a key topic, Bello has taken on zombie homes, convening a task force to address vacant and abandoned structures that released its final report of 24 recommendations earlier this month. The office has started reporting a monthly list of pending foreclosure actions to local governments in an effort to keep leaders there keyed in properties that could become problems if not addressed.

"Zombie properties don't just affect one level of government, they affect local, the towns and villages, city and state, everybody has a role to play and the county clerk is the record keeper so we have a piece of that as well. I think this is showing some creativity in what the Clerk's Office can do, and making the Clerk's Office more relevant."
Bello would not say he'd ruled out a run for higher office, but said he will focus on improving the office.
"I love the job that I have and the way I answer that question is that I focus on doing the best job in the job I'm in and the future will take care of itself," he said.

As for his plans if elected to a four-year term, Bello said he would continue seeking ways to modernize the office and make it more efficient, piggybacking on his initiatives to offer appointments for Department of Motor Vehicles services and the upcoming switch to e-filing

The Monroe County Clerk's Office is the repository for county records and is in charge of being registrar of deeds, mortgages, judgments and liens, offers passport services and supervises state Department of Motor Vehicle services. The four-year elected position has a salary of $81,000 per year and the office has a $3.3 million budget.
MCDERMOT@Gannett.com
Adam Bello
Age: 36
Education: B.A. in political science, Binghamton University
Party lines: Democratic, Working Families
Background: Appointed Monroe County clerk in March by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo

The position: Monroe County Clerk's Office is the repository for county records and is in charge of being registrar of deeds, mortgages, judgments and liens, offers passport services and supervises state Department of Motor Vehicle services. The four-year elected position has a salary of $81,000 per year and the office has a $3.3 million budget.
About the candidate: Bello is a former aide to state Senate Majority Leader Joseph Morelle, D-Irondequoit, former executive director of the Monroe County Democratic Party, chief administrator for the Monroe County District Attorney and was elected Irondequoit town supervisor in 2014.
Top goal: To modernize the office and make services there more efficient.
Cheryl Rozzi
Age: 55
Party lines: Republican, Conservative, Independence, Reform
Education: B.A. in English, State University College at Fredonia.
Background: Greece town clerk since 2014

The position: Monroe County Clerk's Office is the repository for county records and is in charge of being registrar of deeds, mortgages, judgments and liens, offers passport services and supervises state Department of Motor Vehicle services. The four-year elected position has a salary of $81,000 per year and the office has a $3.3 million budget.
About the candidate: Rozzi has nearly three decades of experience in Monroe County departmental administration and served for 11 years as deputy clerk and then clerk of the Monroe County Legislature. She and her husband, Rick Rozzi, owned Atlas Fitness in Spencerport from 1995 to 2004.
Top goal: To enhance customer service within the clerk’s office.

articleBody.value: Two months ago Greece Town Justice
Charles Schiano Jr. looked like he'd have clear sailing to the open judicial seat for the Seventh Judicial District.
Now there are three candidates, though only Schiano and Democrat
Tonia Ettinger are actively campaigning. The third candidate — Syracuse attorney

Mimi Satter — is simply a placeholder on the ballot and not campaigning. (More on that oddity — namely why is a lawyer from Syracuse on the ballot and why couldn't the Working Families find someone locally —  to come later.)
Schiano, 54, has served as Greece town justice since 2002. He said during that time he has adjudicated more than 50,000 cases, from landlord-tenant disputes to misdemeanor crimes.

Schiano, who is in law practice with two brothers and his father, said the experience in Greece — one of the state's largest towns — is a solid stepping stone to state Supreme Court, which can handle criminal, civil and matrimonial cases.
"It was something I always wanted to do," he said of state Supreme Court. "The question was when."

Ettinger, 38, had managed the campaign for County Court candidate Matthew Nafus, who lost a Democratic primary to Melissa Barrett. Democrats then opted to place Ettinger, a lawyer with the Legal Aid Society of Rochester, in the open slot for state Supreme Court.
► ELECTION 2016 NEWS AND PREVIEWS: Local races | National races

"I decided to take the initiative and go on the line," said Ettinger, who hopes a solid Democratic turnout can boost her chances Nov. 8. She acknowledged the political difficulty of joining the race shortly before Election Day.
"It's extremely hard," she said. "Schiano has been campaigning since January."

Ettinger entered the election too late to be evaluated by local legal organizations that grade judicial candidates. This year, Republican candidates, including Schiano, boycotted interviews with the organizations after the GOP and Conservative parties claimed the evaluations were unfair. The Monroe County Bar Association still rated candidates based on other information, and found Schiano "highly qualified," the highest rating, while the Greater Rochester Association for Women Attorneys rated him "not recommended" because he did not participate in the process.

Supreme Court races are open to candidates across the state. Satter had been a Working Families candidate for Congress in the 24th Congressional District, but the party opted to cross-endorse the Democratic candidate. However, that decision required Satter to be moved to another ballot line, and she was switched to the state Supreme Court race in the Seventh Judicial District.
An assistant in Satter's office said she is not campaigning, and she did not respond to interview requests.
The Seventh Judicial District consists of Cayuga, Livingston, Monroe, Ontario, Seneca, Steuben, Wayne and Yates counties. The term is 14 years and the salary $193,000.
Tonia Ettinger
Age: 38
Ballot lines: Democratic
Resides: Farmington, Ontario County.
Education: State University College at Geneseo, 1999. University of Buffalo Law School, 2003.

Experience: Private lawyer, 2003-09, handling civil, criminal, matrimonial and Family Court law. Legal Aid Society of Rochester, 2009 to present, largely focused in Family Court and Integrated Domestic Violence Court.

Top priority: "My top priority once elected will be to ensure that I am familiar with each case before I take the bench.  I believe this will provide greater courtroom efficiency and will build confidence in the people who appear before me because I have read the contents of their filings in advance.  Most importantly this will free up time for the litigants and/or their counsel to be heard.  It is my belief that this will ultimately advance the core values of the judiciary, namely integrity, independence, fairness and quality service."
Charles Schiano Jr.
Age: 54
Ballot lines: Republican, Conservative, Independence
Residence: Greece
Education: Niagara University, 1983. University of Dayton Law School, 1986.

Experience: Private practice, Schiano Law Office, 1987 to present, focusing on criminal and civil practices, including death penalty representation. Greece town justice, 2002 to present. Rochester City Court hearing officer. Private mediator/arbitrator.

Top priority: "My top priority is that all litigants who appear in Supreme Court are treated fairly and receive justice. I have been in private practice as a lawyer for 29 years practicing in Supreme Court. I have handled civil, criminal, divorce and commercial claims matters in Supreme Court during these 29 years. I have been a Greece town judge for over 14 years and have adjudicated over 50,000 cases. Since Supreme Court has general jurisdiction of civil and criminal matters I have the experience to efficiently adjudicate these cases. I have also acted as an arbitrator/mediator in civil cases and have been asked by other attorneys to resolve their cases out of court in an expedient fashion. I have the experience to resolve cases for parties in my court in a fair and efficient manner."

articleBody.value: A pair of September primaries for Monroe County Court Judge didn't eliminate any of the three candidates, but set up the main contest between Democrat Melissa Barrett and Republican Sam Valleriani.

Barrett, an associate attorney for the state Supreme Court, handily defeated Matthew Nafus in the Democratic primary. Nafus will still appear on the Women's Equality line, but is not actively campaigning.

Valleriani, a Gates town justice, is on the Republican, Independent, Conservative, Reform and Working Families party lines. He defeated both Barrett and Nafus for the Working Families designation, but it would be unsound to extrapolate that victory into a general election advantage; there are just 1,552 registered Working Families voters, and turnout for the primary was around 10 percent countywide.
► MORE: Barrett, Valleriani prevail in primary
The winner of the election will fill the seat vacated last year by James Piampiano, who was elected to the state Supreme Court. It is a 10-year term, with a salary of $193,000.

Melissa Barrett: Perinton resident; 47 years old. Rated “qualified” by the Monroe County Bar Association; "qualified" by the Independent Judicial Election Qualification Commission; “qualified” by the Greater Rochester Association for Women Attorneys; and “highly qualified” and “highly sensitive” by the Rochester Black Bar Association. www.votemelissabarrett.com.

For the last 14 years Barrett has been an associate court attorney for the state Supreme Court. That impartial position involves helping judges reach decisions in civil and criminal cases, contributing legal research and helping litigants through the court system. Before that,she worked as an assistant district counsel to the U.S. Small Business Administration and in the Public Defender’s Office.
Barrett said she believes she is most qualified for the position because of her experience as associate court attorney and the insight it gives her into how judges work.
In 2007, she ran for Monroe County Family Court judge as a Republican but lost in the party process. She became an enrolled Democrat in 2014.
► ELECTION 2016 NEWS AND PREVIEWS: Local races | National races

Sam Valleriani: Gates resident; 42 years old. He did not participate in any of the four ratings processes; the Monroe County Bar Association nonetheless rated him as "qualified." Valleriani declined to say why he didn't participate in the ratings processes. www.judgevalleriani.com.
Valleriani is in his second term as Gates town justice. Before that, he was a teacher in the Rochester City School District, then an assistant public defender and a lawyer in private practice.

He now works as the court attorney to Monroe County Court Judge John DeMarco, helping with legal research and drafting opinions. Valleriani said he believes he is most qualified because he has experience as a judge and because he is intimately familiar with Monroe County Court.
Election Day is Tuesday, Nov. 8.
JMURPHY7@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: ALBANY - A Rochester resident will be on probation for five years for using his state-issued credit card to pay for limousine rides, a Niagara Falls wedding ceremony and a trip to Darien Lake amusement park.

Donald Chrisman, a former employee in the state Office for People with Developmental Disabilities, was sentenced Thursday in Monroe County Court after pleading guilty to fourth-degree grand larceny in November, according to the state Inspector General's Office.
Chrisman, 46, was ordered to repay the state $16,669 for the unapproved credit-card bills.
"This defendant’s repeated abuse of a taxpayer-backed government credit card was an affront to the public trust,” Inspector General Catherine Leahy Scott said in a statement.
According to the inspector general, Chrisman used his state credit card on personal expenses at least 249 times from June 1, 2015, to Aug. 18, 2015.
Among the charges were $4,000 on limo service to restaurants, Darien Lake and Wal-Mart, as well as to pay for a vow renewal ceremony with his wife at The Falls Wedding Chapel in Niagara Falls.
A former Niagara Falls resident who now lives in Rochester, Chrisman was a peer advocate for the Office for People With Developmental Disabilities from 2003 to early 2016.
JCampbell1@Gannett.com
Jon Campbell is a staff writer with USA TODAY Network's Albany Bureau.

content.author: Jon Campbell, @JonCampbellGAN
content.headline: Rochester man sentenced for credit card abuse
content.description: Donald Chrisman pleaded guilty to using a state credit card for limo services, wedding.

articleBody.value: ALBANY - New York Democrats hoping for a down-ballot boost from Hillary Clinton were left searching for answers after Republican candidates held strong despite Clinton's landslide win in the state.
Clinton racked up a big win Tuesday in her home state, taking home 59 percent of the statewide vote while losing the national race to fellow New Yorker Donald Trump.

But her strong overall showing in New York didn't translate to Democratic wins in most areas of the state. Republicans retained their nine congressional seats and kept a slim majority in the state Senate.
Clinton's support was driven largely by strong support in heavily blue New York City and major cities upstate — areas where there were few contested down-ballot races.
Republicans, meanwhile, were able to capitalize in the Hudson Valley and on Long Island, picking up key wins in regions where Trump remained competitive.

"She did very well in New York City, but she did poorly upstate and she lost on Long Island," said state Sen. Michael Gianaris, a Queens Democrat who heads his party's re-election efforts in the Senate.
"So the coattails were not what we were expecting."
The four counties where Clinton performed best Tuesday were all New York City boroughs: Bronx, Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens, each of which she won with at least 75 percent of the vote.
She also won Westchester County with 64 percent of the vote, which aided state Sen. George Latimer, D-Rye, who warded off a challenge from Republican Julie Killian.
Further north, Republican Sens. Terrence Murphy of Yorktown, Westchester County, and Sue Serino of Hyde Park, Dutchess County, were able to cruise to re-election.
The pair of incumbents were helped in part by Trump's strong showing in Putnam and Dutchess counties, which he won with 57 percent and 48 percent of the vote, respectively.
State GOP chairman Ed Cox said Trump supporters carried Republican candidates in key races.
"Where we had real fights on our hands, Donald Trump was there being helpful to us," Cox said. "The troops that he was getting out to vote was a tremendous help to us in our success."
Gianaris, meanwhile, said Democratic candidates performed well on Long Island despite Trump's strong showing there.

In a television interview Wednesday, Gov. Andrew Cuomo — a longtime Clinton supporter — said Clinton's defeat was "emotional" for him. Cuomo said he spoke to Trump via phone Wednesday and had a "good conversation."
"I think Donald Trump being from New York is the bonus not just for New York, but for other states, also," Cuomo said.
Trump's down-ballot coattails, meanwhile, appear to have benefited Republicans nationwide.
The GOP was able to retain its majority in the U.S House and Senate, which will keep Sen. Charles Schumer from becoming Senate majority leader.
"Donald Trump provided the kind of coattails that got a lot of people over the finish line so that we can maintain our majorities in the House and Senate," House Speaker Paul Ryan said Wednesday.
JCampbell1@Gannett.com
Jon Campbell is a staff writer with USA TODAY Network's Albany Bureau.

content.author: Jon Campbell, @JonCampbellGAN
content.headline: Clinton coattails nonexistent in NY races
content.description: Few Democrats across NY received a down-ballot boost from Clinton.
